4350/A0/05/883/002.indicator_name: UNICEF-targeted children and women who experienced or at risk of experiencing sexual violence and received at least one kind of multi-sectoral support services in humanitarian situations
4350/A0/05/883/002.headline: Violence prevention programmes focusing on preventing and responding to child marriage and other forms of gender-based violence were implemented in geographical locations characterized by high numbers of vulnerable Turkish children and refugee children.

4350/A0/05/883/001.indicator_name: Number of refugee child/adolescent girls and boys with access to non-formal or informal education opportunities
4350/A0/05/883/001.headline: 9 249 Syrian children (4 866 girls and 4 383 boys) received needs-based informal education opportunities. UNICEF continued working with MoNE Secondary Education Directorate General (SEDG) to strengthen quality inclusive education opportunities for vulnerable adolescent girls and boys to prevent non-attendance and drop-out and promote gender and child rights education.

4350/A0/04/800/001.status_value: approved in February  updated in June
4350/A0/04/800/001.indicator_name: Oversight structures are in place and functioning

4350/A0/04/800/001.status_value: regularly  used for the CMT meetings as well.
updated with the ToA in June
updated in May and relevant audit recommendation was closed.
4350/A0/04/800/001.indicator_name: Risk Management and Business Continuity implementation

4350/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: % of local coordination committees monitoring the follow-up of judicial decisions on diversion to alternative measures

4350/A0/04/002/006.status_value: As per 2014 Judicial Statistics released on October 2015  %22.7 of the child court decisions are on imprisonment.  No segregated data on the decisions of the general courts concerning children.
4350/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: % of court decisions diverting children to alternatives to detention
4350/A0/04/002/006.baseline_value: 23% of decisions were security orders in 2008

4350/A0/04/002/006.status_value: 20 institutions covering almost 70 % of children in prison (by end 2015) used B¿S¿S
4350/A0/04/002/006.indicator_name: Number of penitenciary institutions hosting minors which use individualised rehabilitation programmes
4350/A0/04/002/006.baseline_value: 4 institutions covering 3% of children in prison in 2010

4350/A0/04/800/002.indicator_name: Accounting & Finance: Timely completion of closure of accounts
Accounting & Finance: Cash Forecast and Monthly Bank Balances
Accounting & Finance: % of expenditure for IB and Cross Sectoral RR

4350/A0/05/882/001.indicator_name: Capacity (availability of tools  expertize  internal policies  information) of relevant CSOs and institutions to generate evidence on the situation of children in line with international good practices
4350/A0/05/882/001.headline: Two national CSO networks targeting vulnerable children increased their evidence-generation capacity for monitoring child rights. Policy dialogue with the Government on the 2030 Agenda and a joint mapping of SDG indicators will inform the national plans to adapt data collection systems vis-a-vis the SDGs.
4350/A0/05/882/001.baseline_value: Availability of tools  expertize  policies and information limited especially among CSOs

4350/A0/04/002/005.status_value: No comprehensive data. MoYS youth survey under discussion
4350/A0/04/002/005.indicator_name: % of youth benefiting from national youth services
4350/A0/04/002/005.baseline_value: 30% youth are aware and 2-5% youth are benefitting directly from youth services (camps and centres) ¿ Source: Youth profile survey March 2012 (SETA on behalf of MOFSP)

4350/A0/04/002/005.status_value: MoYS youth survey under discussion with UNICEF for data collection/update
4350/A0/04/002/005.indicator_name: Proportion of local youth councils participating in youth policy implementation

4350/A0/04/001/012.status_value: No particular action during the second half of 2015 due to double elections.
4350/A0/04/001/012.indicator_name: Number of actions taken by the Parliament Child Rights Monitoring Committee which result in a change in legislation  regulations  policies and practices in line with the CRC
4350/A0/04/001/012.baseline_value: The Child Rights Monitoring Committee of Parliament is established and communication channels to collect data from local level child rights committees are functioning

4350/A0/04/001/012.status_value: Between June and December 2015  65 (29 found inadmissable) applications from children were received rights through the website. No segregated data available for other type of applications.
4350/A0/04/001/012.indicator_name: Number of cases filed with an independent legislatively mandated fully funded Child Ombudsperson

4350/A0/04/001/011.indicator_name: % of foster parents who are trained and regularly monitored
4350/A0/04/001/011.baseline_value: Alternative care providers not systematically monitored but social services plan to increase monitoring and guidance

4350/A0/04/001/011.status_value: Self- assessment system was operational at 256 child care centers out of 650. 5749 children  4166 staff members and 626 families at the centers were benefited from the system.
4350/A0/04/001/011.indicator_name: % of children in institutions using minimum standards  as a basis for informed periodic review of placement

4350/A0/04/001/011.status_value: No update since Dec 2015  except closer monitoring of Southeastern provinces. Target reached  despite high disparities across the country and on-line system still to be used.
4350/A0/04/001/011.indicator_name: Number of relevant government institutions at central and local level that systematically exchange child-related data for prevention and protection purposes

4350/A0/04/001/010.status_value: The latest version of the legal reform is completed by the MoFSP and provided to the MoH in May 2015. Due to the current political situation  the legal reform is delayed. It is expected to be approved by the end of 2015.The latest version of the legal reform on the Medical Report Process for Children with Special Needs (COZGER) is completed by the MoFSP and provided to the MoH in May 2015. Due to two general elections and temporary Government in place in the last six months  the legal reform is
4350/A0/04/001/010.indicator_name: Functional disability reporting system addressing childhood disability (ages 0-18)
4350/A0/04/001/010.baseline_value: The existing system does not address children separately.

4350/A0/04/001/010.status_value: Job analysis for nurses report is under process of the publishing at the MoH ¿ TPHI ¿ Department for Family Medicine Education and Development. Due to two general elections taken place in Turkey in the last six months and as the ECD remote training is directly related to the approval of the legal change for the new reporting system (COZGER)  completion of the ECD remote training module is delayed to 2016.  1st International Developmental Pediatrics Congress is succesfully finalised in December 2
4350/A0/04/001/010.indicator_name: % increase in healthcare providers (family physicians  pediatricians  nurses  child development specialists) and of units responsible for the provision of primary health care competentily administering comprehensive Child survival and Development practices  as determined through regular monitoring

4350/A0/04/001/010.status_value: The set of indicators has been developed with the Mother and Child health team. Technical and software integration into the e-system is completed. No new information available.
4350/A0/04/001/010.indicator_name: A set of core indicators related to the continuum of care (as it relates to under-5 health and development) is integrated in teh PHC/Family medicine monitoring system/database

4350/A0/04/800/888.indicator_name: Addressing staff capacity and competency gaps

4350/A0/04/800/888.status_value: LJCC met two times until June. Staff Survey results are also addressed in detail.
4350/A0/04/800/888.indicator_name: Effective and useful communication between the Management and the Staff Association

4350/A0/05/882/002.indicator_name: Capacity (procedures  mechanisms  expertize) of Ombudsman Office  National Human Rights Institution (NHRI)  the Parliament and networks of child rights civil society groups to monitor and report on child rights violations
4350/A0/05/882/002.headline: Despite some delays  further steps were taken in highlighting the role and strengthening the capacity of the Ombudsperson Institution for child rights monitoring  including through enhanced international exchange on best practices  while effective advocacy continued at the parliamentary level.
4350/A0/05/882/002.baseline_value: Ombudsman Office  NHRI  Parliament and existing networks of child rights civil society groups have limited capacity to monitor and report on child rights violations

4350/A0/04/003/003.status_value: Supply Plan is updated regularly and bidding processes  CRCs have been completed. L3 simplifications are being used.
4350/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: Timely completion of bidding processes and CRCs

4350/A0/04/003/003.status_value: in-place  all committees updated and functioning
4350/A0/04/003/003.indicator_name: % of Office Management Committees fully functioning as per ToRs established

4350/A0/04/002/004.status_value: Same as previously reported (All 3 research studies conducted. Reports finalized. Approved Policy Recommendation Report disseminated. OOSSC- Turkey Report waiting for Minister's approval)
4350/A0/04/002/004.indicator_name: Causes of class repetition & drop-out from secondary education identified and disseminated among concerned government departments and other partners (Yes/No)
4350/A0/04/002/004.baseline_value: Causes of class repetition &drop-out from secondary education not identified and disseminated.

4350/A0/04/002/004.status_value: 11  221 in total (9905 secondary school age children benefited from the Orientation Program that was developed  piloted twice and evaluated and 316 secondary school age children with the first pilot of the intervention model  both of which have the potential to be integrated into the in-service trainings of MoNE in 2016 program to avoid drop-outs meaning that all secondary school age children targeted will benefit from increased teacher capacity in this regard. 1000 students at 9th Grade benefit
4350/A0/04/002/004.indicator_name: Number of secondary school age children benefiting from targeted prevention of drop-out interventions implemented nation-wide

4350/A0/04/003/005.indicator_name: # of children benefiting from seasonal clothing
# of school-aged children (boys and girls aged 4-18) in camps and host communities in schools/learning programmes
# conflict-affected boys and girls with equitable access to child protection or psychosocial support services  including in Child-Friendly spaces and mobile units

4350/A0/05/881/005.indicator_name: Responsible ministry/ department/ professionals use properly available equipment such as one way screens  CCTV  functioning recording technology and communication/ testimonial aids (RKLA)
4350/A0/05/881/005.headline: Analyses were conducted and legal frameworks drafted with a view to increasing the quality of various components of the child-friendly justice system  and strategic partnerships were established to facilitate access to quality legal aid for children in contact with the law.
4350/A0/05/881/005.baseline_value: Judicial Interview Rooms for Children (JIRC) established in 23 provinces but not yet operationalized

4350/A0/05/881/006.indicator_name: # of adolescents (10-17 years old) and young people (18-29 years old) (UTP and Turkish) participating in social cohesion mechanisms
4350/A0/05/881/006.headline: Programmes to support social cohesion among adolescents in communities with high numbers of refugees - thereby strengthening the social fabric and reducing risks of segregation and conflict - and to build the capacities of adolescents to claim and uphold their rights were expanded and are set to expand further.

4350/A0/05/881/006.indicator_name: # of municipalities with high concentration of vulnerable children (child workers and children UTP) with inclusive child participation mechanisms
4350/A0/05/881/006.headline: Programmes to support social cohesion among adolescents in communities with high numbers of refugees - thereby strengthening the social fabric and reducing risks of segregation and conflict - and to build the capacities of adolescents to claim and uphold their rights were expanded and are set to expand further.

4350/A0/05/881/001.status_value: 13 000 (100% of the Syrian volunteer teachers - therefore target achieved in terms of %)
4350/A0/05/881/001.indicator_name: # of Syrian teachers operating under the ¿Management strategy for education personnel providing services to children under temporary protection¿
4350/A0/05/881/001.headline: As of December 2016  over 490 000 Syrian children were enrolled in formal education  including both public schools and temporary education centres (TECs). UNICEF contributed by strengthening the formal education system and enhancing access for Syrian children and adolescents to formal schooling.
4350/A0/05/881/001.baseline_value: 8 716 Syrian teachers operating as ¿volunteer teachers¿ and receiving a financial incentive under the current management strategy

4350/A0/05/881/001.indicator_name: School-aged children and adolescents in affected areas back in school (including early childhood education programmes) after interruption or newly enrolled since the emergency - number & percent
4350/A0/05/881/001.headline: As of December 2016  over 490 000 Syrian children were enrolled in formal education  including both public schools and temporary education centres (TECs). UNICEF contributed by strengthening the formal education system and enhancing access for Syrian children and adolescents to formal schooling.

4350/A0/05/881/003.indicator_name: UNICEF-targeted children in humanitarian situations benefitting from psychosocial support
4350/A0/05/881/003.headline: Engagement with the GoT and CSOs was enhanced to strengthen the capacity of child protection systems to prevent  detect early  and respond to child protection cases. Emphasis was placed on ensuring access to child protection services across the continuum of care for all children  including refugee and migrant children.

4350/A0/05/881/002.indicator_name: Pre- and in-service teacher training includes modules on special needs and inclusion issues (RKLA)
4350/A0/05/881/002.headline: The education system was strengthened to increase its inclusiveness and quality through improved standards  curricula and learning environments  strengthened professional development systems (including certified training for 19 776 Syrian volunteer teachers)  enhanced learning assessment and education management information systems  and expanded inclusive quality early childhood education.
4350/A0/05/881/002.baseline_value: National pre- and in-service teacher training programmes do not adequately incorporate components on inclusive education

4350/A0/05/881/002.indicator_name: # of trained Syrian volunteer teachers certified by MoNE
4350/A0/05/881/002.headline: The education system was strengthened to increase its inclusiveness and quality through improved standards  curricula and learning environments  strengthened professional development systems (including certified training for 19 776 Syrian volunteer teachers)  enhanced learning assessment and education management information systems  and expanded inclusive quality early childhood education.

4350/A0/05/881/002.indicator_name: Availability of data on vulnerable students from education management information systems (EMIS)
4350/A0/05/881/002.headline: The education system was strengthened to increase its inclusiveness and quality through improved standards  curricula and learning environments  strengthened professional development systems (including certified training for 19 776 Syrian volunteer teachers)  enhanced learning assessment and education management information systems  and expanded inclusive quality early childhood education.
4350/A0/05/881/002.baseline_value: EMIS for refugee student data rolled out. Data on students in need of counselling not systematically tracked

4350/A0/04/001/007.status_value: Official national data is not available. According to the research undertaken by KAH¿P  a joint platform composed of several NGOs  budget allocated for children including education was equal to 3.43% of GDP in 2011. This is the latest data available and there is a statement that data after 2011 is not transparent. UNICEF CO has started a pilot study among three municipalities for budget analysis through child rights  which might be replicated by others.
4350/A0/04/001/007.indicator_name: Share in national budget allocated for children
4350/A0/04/001/007.baseline_value: There is no information on the share of the budget directly or indirectly benefitted by children

4350/A0/04/001/007.status_value: An inter-sectoral working group on child well-being is established and indicators are finalized. Child Labour Monitoring Units established by the Ministry are closed and no replacement has been put in place yet  but discussions are ongoing between MOLSS  MOD and UNICEF.
4350/A0/04/001/007.indicator_name: Relevant institutions make use of disaggregated data on child poverty  child well being and child labour to design  adjust and monitor policies with a view to increasing equity among children
4350/A0/04/001/007.baseline_value: Poverty and welfare data are not disaggregated geographically.Child Poverty and well being are not specifically monitored. Child labour is not monitored regularly in line with international definitions.

4350/A0/04/001/007.status_value: Minimum share of income per person within a household is set as eligibility criteria. Most disadvantaged families  including the information on the number of benefitting children though not disaggregated.
4350/A0/04/001/007.indicator_name: Formula in effect for allocating social assistance in directing resources towards the most disadvantaged children

4350/A0/04/001/008.indicator_name: Percentage of schools/institutions providing pre-school education which strengthened their institutional capacity and implement the updated programmes with a view to increase equitable provision  quality and demand.

4350/A0/04/001/008.status_value: By end of 2015  3425 young children are benefiting from Community based ECE centers in Turkey.
4350/A0/04/001/008.indicator_name: Number of children benefiting from quality-community based early childhood development services within the scope of a regulatory framework
Percentage of 48-66 months old children with a disability enrolled in inclusive pre-primary education.
4350/A0/04/001/008.baseline_value: Out of the 20.000 5 years old children with a disability 2 94% (588 children) with special needs are enrolled in inclusive preschool education

4350/A0/04/001/008.status_value: Same as previously reported (More than 25 000 teachers  principals and inspectors applying the revised child centered programmes)
4350/A0/04/001/008.indicator_name: Number of implementers (teachers  principals and inspectors) who have attended in service training and practice/apply the revised child centred programmes

4350/A0/04/001/008.status_value: 2012: 345 pilot institutions/schools are currently implementing the revised inclusive curriculum  reaching 8250 children age 0-6 year. Furthermore  as a result of additional capacity building efforts  a total of 126 050 children age 0-6 are now benefitting from inclusive child-centered curriculum.
4350/A0/04/001/008.indicator_name: number and % annual increase in schools/institutions providing preschool education which benefit from and implement upgraded institutional arrangements and programmes with a view to increasing equitable provision  quality and demand.

4350/A0/04/001/008.status_value: Work is in progress: the first community based centres are being set up  standards are beign piloted and licensing system is under development
4350/A0/04/001/008.indicator_name: Ratio of providers of community -based day care and pre-school education services  governed by quality standards  a licensing system adn a regulatory framework  to total pre-school education providers in ten provinces

4350/A0/04/001/009.status_value: MoNE is the main implementing partner of EU funded projects aiming to decrease non-attendance in primary education institutions through qualitative measures and interventions.
4350/A0/04/001/009.indicator_name: Number of coordinated responses (institutional changes  resource allocations  C4D actions) adopted by the Ministry of Education for increased access to and completion of quality primary education for OOS children

4350/A0/04/001/009.status_value: The MoNE is still working on the school  district  provincial and national level data. A report is not expected till the data formulations are entered into the Education Institutions' Standards (EIS) system.
4350/A0/04/001/009.indicator_name: % of schools addressing capacity gaps in the delivery of inclusive quality education identified through standardized monitoring tools.
